item.title: Inflation is not ‘defeated’
item.description: Trump cannot convince consumers that prices have fallen, but he can reset expectations around costs.

item.description: Michael Ramirez cartoon on Renée Good’s death and public support for ICE.

item.title: Journalists face more peril a decade after Iran freed a Post reporter
item.description: When Jason Rezaian was released, 199 other reporters were in prison. That’s jumped 80 percent.

item.title: The world is adjusting to an unreliable United States
item.description: Years of accumulated trust are being spent for short-term leverage.

item.description: A long history shows what not to do when trying to encourage political change in a foreign land

item.title: Answering your questions about this season’s respiratory viruses
item.description: Flu cases are surging and federal health officials are changing vaccine recommendations. Here’s what you should know.

item.title: I used to have 100 employees. Now I have 70. Thanks, Trump.

item.title: The facts about nuclear energy are sinking in. Even in Illinois.
item.description: Gov. JB Pritzker (D), eyeing 2028, finally abandons the state’s ban on new nuclear plants.

item.description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. wants to flood the vaccine injury compensation program to hurt vaccine access in the U.S.

item.description: A bet on government action by a government actor is always a bet against the public interest.

item.description: The president’s first term was committed to the free market. His second, not so much.

item.description: Tehran shouldn’t expect Trump to repeat Obama’s mistakes.

item.description: Divided government would be good outcome next fall.

item.title: What Renée Good’s killing says about U.S. citizenship
item.description: The government’s battle over who belongs seeks to reshape the nation’s identity.

item.title: Something is wrong in Chicago — and it concerns hot dogs
item.description: Chicago’s political culture prioritizes who you know, rather than how well you serve customers.

item.title: Dry January? Sometimes drinking is part of the solution.
item.description:
Journalist Katie Herzog was 12 years old when she first drank alcohol. It wasn’t until her 30s that she decided to quit. She tried everything — Alcoholics Anonymous, cleanses, therapy, yoga — but nothing stuck. Eventually, she turned to an unorthodox approach: the Sinclair Method.
Katie joins host Megan McArdle to explain this science-based path to sobriety and how it inspired her book, "Drink Your Way Sober."

item.title: Mamdani is showing Democrats the way beyond wokeness
item.description: The NYC mayor offers a new blueprint against cultural division.

item.title: A casino bill is a bad bet for Virginia Democrats
item.description: Few issues have divided Democratic lawmakers as sharply as the proposed Tysons casino.

item.title: Trump wants $1.5 trillion for defense. What a bargain.
item.description: Trump’s push for a higher defense budget, while hard to achieve, is the right impulse.
